title: Neuropsychological markers of mild cognitive impairment

author: Simon Brezovar, Department of Neurology, University Medical Centre Ljubljana

segmentation: Thank you Professor Peterschick for such a nice introduction.

We talk and of course I would also like to thank organizers for inviting me and for giving me an opportunity to share with you some of the results which were collected in our ARS studies, as it was already mentioned.

So I would like to start with this picture, which is kind of a must know picture for for all the researchers we're working with with early diagnosis, early biomarkers of dementia, and we can see very clearly from this picture that.

We can observe some particular part of physiological processes in Alzheimer's disease and also in other dementia which can be observed actually many years before someone enters the neurological clinic with memory and other cognitive complaints.
And in this slide actually very important concept of already mentioned mild cognitive impairment arose at about 15 years ago.
In Mayo Clinic by by run by Ron Peterson.
And so mild cognitive impairment is understand is understood as intermediate stage between the expected cognitive decline expected.
So for normal aging and dementia.
And it's important this big cause it's somehow represents increased risk of later progression of later progression to dementia.

We know from different studies which vary lots becausw they used very different methodology, but according to the study of Grundman colleagues 10 to 15% of patients with mild cognitive impairment each year progress to progress to dementia.
And what is also important for my cognitive impairment is that cognitive functioning is impaired.
It is not impaired to such extent as in dementia, but it declines from normal aging, but the normal functioning is is still alright, so they can still be independent in daily daily active.
Um, we we know that we have different subtypes of mild cognitive impairment depends on which cognitive domain is actually affected and how many cognitive domains are affected.
So according to these two criteria, we can have four different subtypes of mild cognitive impairment.
If someone has problems with just with the memory, this is single domain and mastic MCI.
If there are also some other Europe psychological changes.

With memory we said that we have a mastic MCI multiple domain and on the other hand if the patients don't have problems with memory but just with other cognitive domain, we have actually known mastic single or multiple remain mild cognitive impairment.
As Professor Peterschick already set.
Till till recent the concept of mild cognitive impairment was especially associated with dementia.
I mean which primary dementia like especially with Alzheimer's disease and with frontal temporal dementia and so on and so on.
But in last year some researchers and clinicians also try to somehow infiltrate the concept of mild cognitive impairment.
Also to some other diseases such as such as mild cognitive.
Sorry, such as Parkinson Disease where cognitive changes are one of the most common nonmotor symptoms.
And according to study of Boardman and Litwin, MCI is quite common in Nondemented PD patients occurring in about 20 to 50%.

And because of different underlying pathophysiology changes in much cognitive impairment in patients with Parkinson's disease are a bit different as opposed to, let's say, dementia of Alzheimer's type.
So we can expect that in a PD MCI patients there will be more changes in non domestic domains such as executive function.
Attention and visual spatial function.

But recent studies and this is really interesting, pointed out that cognitive phenotype of PD MCI is also quite heterogeneous and that we can have also some patients who demonstrate deficits in amnestic in so in memory in memory domain.
So let me just briefly explain what was actual motivation for our study, why we did that.
Of course, the primary motivation was to better understand.
What are the early cognitive?
What are the early cognitive changes in patients with mild cognitive impairment as well as in Parkinson's disease?
Mild cognitive impairment.
We wanted to contrast the differences in cognitive processing between different neurological diseases in early stage.

We know that patients with Alzheimer's Alzheimer's disease have this more kind of a cortical dementia in patients with Parkinson's is more subcortical dementia, but it is not quite well established what actually happens in early stage of these new logical diseases.
And of course, we want to.
We wanted to assess potential mechanisms of these changes by means of different research tools like TTI Electron, civil ography, CSF.
Average PET scan and some of these results are going to be presented today by some other speakers also.
At at the end, we want to follow our subjects longitudinally and to assess what what is the predicted.
What is the predictive power if we combine different different methods or or so biomarkers?
So some basic information about the sample were already presented.

And since I think I have two or three minutes more, Professor Peter should, because so I would just like to presidential very briefly, for those of you who are not so familiar with neuro psychological testing, becausw, some other speakers will also refer to it.
I just want you to present how different neuro psychological that is actually work.
And what are we assessing with it with them?
So we used actually variety of different tests, which are also recommended by.
Hi Variety Workgroup school for dealing with MCI patients.
So we're using the test like tower test and an Stroop test to assess more this frontal functions and executive function.
Ability to plan.

Ability to inhibit automated response where they have to name the color, which conflicts with the words and when they have to arrange when they have to arrange some material according to one model which is which is given to them.
We use two different tests to assess verbal memory like verbal learning test.

This is Rey auditory verbal learning class, but we used California verbal learning test and we use tray figure to assess the visual memory and we can also set with this test some visual spatial functions and.
And also executive function.
Used also verbal fluency test, which is kind of tests which measure with which we measure more verbal functioning.
But also it is highly saturated by by frontal frontal lobe function heart actually to decompose all these cognitive domains just with one test.
So where subjects has two subjects have to tell us as many animals as they can.
Then they have to tell us on the 1st letter as many words as they can on the letter S and when they have to combine different categories.

So here sorry, car salad struck speech motor where they have to combine different vehicles and different in different vegetables and we use of course well known trail making tests where they have to connect the numbers or just the letters or they have to switch between numbers and letters.
Also test which is highly saturated by bifrontal bifrontal dysfunction and at the end we used also digit span.
Forwards to assess attentional span and you spend backwards to assess working memory.
So just to get just to have a image what what we have done with all this with all these tests?
And what I'm going to present you now is just a brief.
It's just a brief comparison between the four different groups which we take into account.
Across all these modalities, across all these cognitive domains, which were assessed by tests which I which I presented to you.
So we didn't found we didn't find any differences between four groups regarding digit, span forward and digit span and digit span backwards, but.

We find actually we found quite prominent differences regarding cognitive speed, the speed to the speed of mental processing, especially when we looked for the switching process, especially when we look for the switching.
You can see actually that differences are quite great if we used.
If you stay Noah, but when we compare when we compared with the Post blog post hoc tests we can find just the differences between the control.
And MCI, and control and.
Parkinson disease MCI.
But not with controlling Parkinson's disease.
And also among other also among other groups.
If we move forward, we also found some significant differences in verbal memory in verbal memory tests, but what is again quite interesting?
There was no.
There were no differences found with within, so between MCP when we compared the group of mild cognitive impairment, patients and Parkinson's disease.
Sorry here is B, but it should be a deep buckets buckets.
This MCI patients, so this is the test where they have to.
Recall where they have to recall words freely without any Q, but when we give two subjects Q like like a category of the words which they have to tell us back we.
We found it quite the same results.
Differences were maybe even more pronounced than in free, then in free recalled, but again, the differences here between these two groups were absent.
And you will see that this is actually the trend across the all results.

Also when we look the visual memory test, we can find it is quite clear that all these subgroups came from the different population, but there are no expected differences between these groups which we.
Will expect, according to, according to the theory.
Here we have the results of of verbal fluency performance, so where they have to where they have to give us the words to the.
To the letter to the category and when they have to where they have to switch.
This is switching fluency.
I'm sorry for the lapse, as we can see actually that we can see quite quite the same situation then in the slide the slides.
The slides before.
This is the power test.
Where the highest so where the highest number means better performance.
These are achievement scores, so the price is the number.
The better subjects, the better subjects perform and we can see again that control action the subject from control group performed the best, but again, no differences between these two groups and.
The same situation was also in Stroop test, where the highest amount mean how many how many numbers of words they were able to.
They were able to inhibit.
So it's that was that was really actually.
I have to go really fast because I don't have enough time.
We're just about to perform some additional more complex analysis.
Also want to calculate kind of kind of a components which are maybe more more robust, more robust and and to see if we will find some additional differences here.
But what is really interesting is that OK with most of our neuro psychological tests, we were able to differentiate subgroups in our sample.
It seems that especially with switching tests in.
Austria making and long delay free recall in California verbal learning test.
They can differentiate the best so they all they they differ at the greatest, the greatest amount.
But what was what was really differences?
And I think I will refer at this point.
Professor Pizza Shack is that there were no differences between MCI and PPD MCI because there is different underlying pathophysiology.
We will expect.
Actually we would expect.
There will be some differences also also in the level of cognition, but it wasn't the case in our study and it's really interesting question why so?
Um?
But it is again.
I have to mention that Goldman and Littman already said that patients with Parkinson's disease and MCI has very little genius cognitive phenotype.
And maybe this is also the case in our study.
So we just.
We have just inspected what kind of.
What kind of?
Subjects were actually in this MCI and PD MCI groups and we.

Can see again from the sample from the sample that just 12 of just 12 of the patients in MCI groups were uromastyx MCI and the other eight patients were actually non istick MCI, so they did have more executive function problems or other problems and.
The same is also the case in the patients with Parkinson's disease and mild cognitive impairment.
We would expect that they will be impaired, especially in non amnestic MCI according to theory.
But we can see actually that OK.

Eight of them really had no onomastic mild cognitive impairment, but four of them had domestic type of mild impairment and three of them have actually mixed type or multiple domain cognitive impairment.
So we can maybe ask ourself ourselves.
There also is are really more subgroups of PD, MCI and according to our results I think this is quite this is quite a strong.
This is quite a strong option, so we I think we are not allowed to divide so strictly different types of cognitive of cognitive decline.
So I would like to conclude my lecture with just the presentation of some plans which we have.
Will see actually, but these are maybe some ideas for the future.
What can we?
What can we do?
Of course really nice.
Would it be to combine?

Because we have right now a lot of biomarkers, so it would be nice to combine neuropsychological results with other with other with other biomarkers and you will see actually some some triangles in later talks.
Of course, the good idea would be also to increase the number of participants, especially.

In the group of March of patients with mild cognitive impairment and and PD patients with mild cognitive impairment actually to further subdivide these subgroups, maybe according to the Peterson criteria and to understand better the dynamics and the structure of different of different subgroups, not not just in MCI patient was also in PD MCI patients.

And of course, as I already said at the start of my lecture, I think it's really mandatory to expand our research longitudinally to track changes and assess also the clinical predictability of biomarkers which we which we collected, and I think just with the longitudinal follow.
If we would be able to see how well are all these biomarkers function in our study so.
I think that's all from me, so thanks for your attention.
